controls.label: Severity
controls.description: Category representing the overall severity of the symptom or sign.

termDefinition.description: Category representing the overall severity of the symptom or sign.
termDefinition.comment: Defining values such as mild, moderate or severe in such a way that is applicable to multiple symptoms or signs plus allows multiple users to interpret and record them consistently is not easy. Some organisations extend the value set further with inclusion of additional values such as 'Trivial' and 'Very severe', and/or 'Mild-Moderate' and 'Moderate-Severe', adds to the definitional difficulty and may also worsen inter-recorder reliability issues. Use of 'Life-threatening' and 'Fatal' is also often considered as part of this value set, although from a pure point of view it may actually reflect an outcome rather than a severity. In view of the above, keeping to a well-defined but smaller list is preferred and so the mild/moderate/severe value set is offered, however the choice of other text allows for other value sets to be included at this data element in a template. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the 'Specific details' SLOT.

controls.label: Description of Previous Episodes
controls.description: Narrative description about the course of the symptom or sign during this episode.

termDefinition.description: Narrative description about the course of the symptom or sign during this episode.
termDefinition.comment: For example: a text description of the immediate onset of the symptom, activities that worsened or relieved the symptom, whether it is improving or worsening and how it resolved over weeks.

controls.label: Episode Description
controls.description: Narrative description about the course of the symptom or sign during this episode.

termDefinition.description: Narrative description about the course of the symptom or sign during this episode.
termDefinition.comment: For example: a text description of the immediate onset of the symptom, activities that worsened or relieved the symptom, whether it is improving or worsening and how it resolved over weeks.

at0022.description: Category representing the overall severity of the symptom or sign.

Some organisations extend the value set further with inclusion of additional values such as 'Trivial' and 'Very severe', and/or 'Mild-Moderate' and 'Moderate-Severe', adds to the definitional difficulty and may also worsen inter-recorder reliability issues. Use of 'Life-threatening' and 'Fatal' is also often considered as part of this value set, although from a pure point of view it may actually reflect an outcome rather than a severity. In view of the above, keeping to a well-defined but smaller list is preferred and so the mild/moderate/severe value set is offered, however the choice of other text allows for other value sets to be included at this data element in a template. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the 'Specific details' SLOT.

termDefinition.comment:
Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.

at0002.description: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.
at0002.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

at0003.description: Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.
at0003.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

at0005.description: An assessment of the overall severity of the problem or diagnosis.
at0005.comment: If severity is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant. Note: more specific grading of severity can be recorded using the Specific details SLOT.

at0009.description: Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.
at0009.comment: Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.

at0012.description: Identification of a simple body site for the location of the problem or diagnosis.
at0012.comment:
Coding of the name of the anatomical location with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
Use this data element to record precoordinated anatomical locations. If the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations then use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location within the 'Structured anatomical location' SLOT in this archetype. Occurrences for this data element are unbounded to allow for clinical scenarios such as describing a rash in multiple locations but where all of the other attributes are identical. If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, this data element becomes redundant.

at0030.description: Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.
at0030.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

at0039.description: A structured anatomical location for the problem or diagnosis.
at0039.comment:
Use this SLOT to insert the CLUSTER.anatomical_location or CLUSTER.relative_location archetypes if the requirements for recording the anatomical location are determined at run-time by the application or require more complex modelling such as relative locations.

If the anatomical location is included in the Problem/diagnosis name via precoordinated codes, use of this SLOT becomes redundant.

at0043.description: Details that are additionally required to record as unique attributes of this problem or diagnosis.
at0043.comment: May include structured detail about the grading or staging of the diagnosis; diagnostic criteria, classification criteria or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events.

at0046.description: Structured details for location-, domain-, episode- or workflow-specific aspects of the diagnostic process.
at0046.comment: Use status or context qualifiers with care, as they are variably used in practice and interoperability cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined with the community of use. For example: active status - active, inactive, resolved, in remission; evolution status - initial, interim/working, final; temporal status - current, past; episodicity status - first, new, ongoing; admission status - admission, discharge; or priority status - primary, secondary.

at0069.description: Additional narrative about the problem or diagnosis not captured in other fields.

at0070.description: The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.

at0071.description: Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
at0071.comment: For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

at0072.description: Narrative description about the course of the problem or diagnosis since onset.

at0073.description: The level of confidence in the identification of the diagnosis.

at0077.description: Estimated or actual date/time that signs or symptoms of the problem/diagnosis were first observed.
at0077.comment: Data captured/imported as "Age at onset" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

at0080.description: The diagnosis has been identified with a low level of certainty.

at0081.description: The diagnosis has been identified with a high level of certainty.

at0082.description: The diagnosis has been confirmed against recognised criteria.

at0000.description: Problem-oriented heading in the record of the problem presented by the patient or client

at0001.description: The subjective findings or story told by the person.

at0002.description: The objective findings or observations made by the clinician.

at0003.description: The assessment made by the clinician.

at0004.description: Plans made or procedures carried out.

controls.label: Service name
controls.description: The name of the single service or activity requested.

termDefinition.description: The name of the single service or activity requested.
termDefinition.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

controls.label: Test request
controls.description: Category of service requested.

termDefinition.description: Category of service requested.
termDefinition.comment: Coding of the 'Service type' with a coding system is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code. For example: biochemistry or microbiology laboratory, ultrasound or CT imaging.

controls.label: Description
controls.description: Narrative description about the service requested.

termDefinition.description: Narrative description about the service requested.
termDefinition.comment: This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.

controls.label: Reason for request
controls.description: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.

termDefinition.description: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.
termDefinition.comment: Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.

controls.label: Probable Diagnosis
controls.description: The clinical reason for the ordered service.

termDefinition.description: The clinical reason for the ordered service.
termDefinition.comment: Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.

controls.label: Urgency
controls.description: Urgency of the request for service.

termDefinition.description: Urgency of the request for service.
termDefinition.comment: Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. If explicit timing is required then the Service period should be clearly stated.

controls.label: Supplementary information
controls.description: Supplementary information will be following request.

termDefinition.description: Supplementary information will be following request.
termDefinition.comment: Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.

controls.label: Information description
controls.description: Description of the supplementary information.

termDefinition.description: Description of the supplementary information.

controls.label: Comment
controls.description: Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.

termDefinition.description: Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.

at0000.description: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.

at0008.description: @ internal @

at0009.description: @ internal @

at0010.description: The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
at0010.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

at0011.description: The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
at0011.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

at0040.description: The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.
at0040.comment: This data element allows for recording of the timing for a single service, either as a date and time, a date ranges or a text descriptor which can allow for 'next available. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.

at0062.description: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.
at0062.comment: Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.

at0064.description: Narrative description about the reason for request.
at0064.comment: For example: 'The patient's diabetes has recently become more difficult to stabilise and renal function is deteriorating'.

at0065.description: Description of the intent for the request.
at0065.comment: For example: a referral to a specialist may have the intent of the specialist taking over responsibility for care of the patient, or it may be to provide a second opinion on treatment options. Coding of the 'Intent' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

at0068.description: Urgency of the request for service.
at0068.comment: Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. If explicit timing is required then the Service period should be clearly stated.

at0076.description: Supplementary information will be following request.
at0076.comment: Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.

at0112.description: Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
at0112.comment: For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

at0116.description: Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.

at0121.description: The name of the single service or activity requested.
at0121.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

at0127.description: The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester.
at0127.comment: Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

at0128.description: Details of additional clinicians, organisations or agencies who require copies of any communication.

at0132.description: Additional detail about the service requested.
at0132.comment: For example: Specimen details for a laboratory test request, or anatomical location for a procedure request.

at0135.description: Narrative description about the service requested.
at0135.comment: This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.

at0138.description: The request does not require prioritised scheduling.

at0141.description: Details about the clinician or organisation requesting the service.

at0142.description: Details about the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.

at0144.description: The date/time that marks the conclusion of the clinically valid period of time for delivery of this service.
at0144.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the latest possible date for service delivery or to the date of expiry for this request. For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.

at0145.description: The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for delivery of this service.
at0145.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the earliest possible date for service delivery. For example: sometimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some procedures can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking medications for a specific amount of time.

at0147.description: The valid period for this request is open ended and has no date of expiry.
at0147.comment: Record as TRUE to record explicity that the request has no expiry date. For example: commonly required for a referral to a specialist for long-term or lifelong care.

at0148.comment: Coding of the 'Service type' with a coding system is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code. For example: biochemistry or microbiology laboratory, ultrasound or CT imaging.

at0149.description: Digital document, image, video or diagram supplied as additional information to support or inform the request.

at0150.description: Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.

at0151.description: Details about a complex service request requiring a sequence of timings.
at0151.comment: For example: 'hourly vital signs observations for 4 hours, then 4 hourly for 20 hours' or 'every third Wednesday for 3 visits' or .

at0152.description: The clinical reason for the ordered service.
at0152.comment: Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.

at0144.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the latest possible date for service delivery or to the date of expiry for this request. For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.

at0145.description: The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for delivery of this service.
at0145.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the earliest possible date for service delivery. For example: sometimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some procedures can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking medications for a specific amount of time.

at0147.description: The valid period for this request is open ended and has no date of expiry.
at0147.comment: Record as TRUE to record explicity that the request has no expiry date. For example: commonly required for a referral to a specialist for long-term or lifelong care.

at0148.comment: Coding of the 'Service type' with a coding system is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code. For example: biochemistry or microbiology laboratory, ultrasound or CT imaging.

at0149.description: Digital document, image, video or diagram supplied as additional information to support or inform the request.

at0150.description: Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.

at0151.description: Details about a complex service request requiring a sequence of timings.
at0151.comment: For example: 'hourly vital signs observations for 4 hours, then 4 hourly for 20 hours' or 'every third Wednesday for 3 visits' or .

at0152.description: The clinical reason for the ordered service.
at0152.comment: Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.

controls.label: Medication item
controls.description: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.

termDefinition.description: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.
termDefinition.comment: Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

controls.label: Administration method
controls.description: The technique or device by which the ordered item is to be administered.

termDefinition.description: The technique or device by which the ordered item is to be administered.
termDefinition.comment: For example: ' via Z-track injection'; 'via nebuliser'. Coding of the method with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

controls.label: Overall directions description
controls.description: Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.

termDefinition.description: Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.
termDefinition.comment: This narrative should normally subsume data captured in 'Dose amount', 'Dose timing' and any additional instructions for use. Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.

controls.label: Parsable directions
controls.description: A parsable, computable text representation of the directions.

termDefinition.description: A parsable, computable text representation of the directions.
termDefinition.comment: Generally this is only used when passing information between legacy systems. For example: '10mg bd; 20mg n' as used by the NHS Dose syntax (in development).

controls.label: Specific directions description
controls.description: A narrative description of a specific part of overall directions.

termDefinition.description: A narrative description of a specific part of overall directions.
termDefinition.comment: In some settings, it is common to split overall narrative directions into more specific segments of narrative. For example in hospital settings, it can be common to split the overall directions into 'Dose amount' and 'Dose timing', both as narrative text. These terms can be applied at template or run-time.

controls.label: Additional instruction
controls.description: An additional instruction on how to use or store the ordered item.

termDefinition.description: An additional instruction on how to use or store the ordered item.
termDefinition.comment: For example: precautions as 'take with food', 'Avoid grapefruit', 'Dissolve in water', 'store in a cool, dry place'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible.

controls.label: Patient information
controls.description: An additional instruction directed primarily at the individual/patient or carers.

termDefinition.description: An additional instruction directed primarily at the individual/patient or carers.
termDefinition.comment: For example: 'To reduce your blood pressure', 'To thin your blood'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible. If required it is possible to use a LINK attribute to associate this element with, for example, the 'original diagnosis' in a separate Problem list composition but the indication should be explicitly recorded here, as the link target may change over time.

controls.label: Clinical indication
controls.description: The clinical reason for use of the ordered item.

termDefinition.description: The clinical reason for use of the ordered item.
termDefinition.comment: For example: 'Angina'. Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. It is not intended to carry an indication for administrative authorisation purposes.

controls.label: Comment
controls.description: Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.

termDefinition.description: Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.

at0000.description: An order for a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item for an identified individual.

at0004.description: Unique identifier for the medication order.
at0004.comment: This data element allows for multiple occurrences to be defined more explicitly at run-time, if required.

at0005.description: The amount and units of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic good to be used or administered at one time.

at0008.description: Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
at0008.comment: For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

at0009.description: Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.
at0009.comment: This narrative should normally subsume data captured in 'Dose amount', 'Dose timing' and any additional instructions for use. Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.

at0011.description: A condition which, when met, requires the commencement of administration or use.
at0011.comment: For example: 'Start if symptoms recur'. This is intended for a general pre-condition which should trigger the whole medication course to be started, and not for 'as required' administrations of an ongoing order.

at0012.description: The date and optional time to commence use of the ordered item.

at0013.description: The date and optional time when it is planned to cease use of the ordered item.

at0016.description: A condition which, when met, requires the cessation of administration or use.

at0018.description: The clinical reason for use of the ordered item.
at0018.comment: For example: 'Angina'. Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. It is not intended to carry an indication for administrative authorisation purposes.

at0044.description: An additional instruction on how to use or store the ordered item.
at0044.comment: For example: precautions as 'take with food', 'Avoid grapefruit', 'Dissolve in water', 'store in a cool, dry place'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible.

at0047.description: A parsable, computable text representation of the directions.
at0047.comment: Generally this is only used when passing information between legacy systems. For example: '10mg bd; 20mg n' as used by the NHS Dose syntax (in development).

at0050.description: The time period during which the individual/patient has already been using the ordered item as a part of the intended whole order but prior to the issuance of this order.
at0050.comment: For example: To record that the patient had been taking antibiotics 3 days prior to hospital admission, in the context of a 7 day course.

at0051.description: Details about the maximum, cumulative dose allowed over a defined period for the ordered item.
at0051.comment: For example: 'up to 1gram per day'. This cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of multiple maximum doses that apply to different time periods. Lifetime maximum dose should not be carried here as it refers to multiple orders over time.

at0053.description: The period of time during which the maximum dose is calculated.

at0060.description: The number of administrations of the ordered item that have been completed, as part of the intended whole order but prior to the issuance of this order.
at0060.comment: For example: To record that the patient has taken the two first antibiotic tablets of a three day course, prior to discharge from the hospital to a nursing home.

at0062.description: Details about medication safety for the ordered item.

at0064.description: Confirmation by the prescriber that the normal dose or other safety limit has been overridden due to exceptional circumstances.

at0065.description: Details about the amount of the ordered item to be dispensed.
at0065.comment: This SLOT allows for local variation in the different jurisdictions regarding medication dispensing amount to be managed.

at0069.description: Details of authorisation of the ordered item, including supporting local self-administration, issue and endorsement policies.
at0069.comment: For example: details of repeat/refill supply. This SLOT allows for local variation in the different jurisdictions regarding medication authorisation and re-authorisation to be managed.

at0070.description: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.
at0070.comment: Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

at0091.description: The route by which the ordered item is to be administered into the subject's body.
at0091.comment:
For example: 'oral', 'intravenous', or 'topical'.
Coding of the route with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Multiple potential routes may be specified.

at0092.description: Name of the site of administration of the ordered item.
at0092.comment:
For example: 'left upper arm', 'intravenous catheter right hand'.
 Coding of the body site with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

at0093.description: Structured description of the site of administration of the ordered item.

at0094.description: The technique or device by which the ordered item is to be administered.
at0094.comment: For example: ' via Z-track injection'; 'via nebuliser'. Coding of the method with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

at0095.description: Details of the medical device used to assist administration of the ordered item.

at0105.description: An additional instruction directed primarily at the individual/patient or carers.
at0105.comment: For example: 'To reduce your blood pressure', 'To thin your blood'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible. If required it is possible to use a LINK attribute to associate this element with, for example, the 'original diagnosis' in a separate Problem list composition but the indication should be explicitly recorded here, as the link target may change over time.

at0106.description: An additional instruction directed primarily at the person dispensing the ordered item.
at0106.comment: Example: Detailed instructions for phased dispensing of opiates.

at0107.description: An additional instruction which gives advice on recommended or required monitoring of the ordered item.
at0107.comment: For example: 'Please check renal function in 2 weeks'. This data element allows multiple occurrences.

at0112.description: Summary information about use of the ordered item, such as current status or key dates, generally used in non-prescription contexts.
at0112.comment: Course summary may be required when transmitting medication information between systems or representing a FHIR Medication statement. For example: as part of a referral, emergency patient summary or discharge communication.

at0113.description: Details about the whole medication order.

at0129.description: Directions about the dispensing of the ordered item.

at0130.description: The maximum, cumulative amount of medication which should be administered within the allowed period. The unit for this amount is carried in Maximum amount unit.

at0132.description: Permission for substitution with a bioequivalent item.
at0132.comment: In many jurisdictions, substitution of an ordered item as a generic form or with a different brand name, which has been determined as bioequivalent, is allowed at the point of dispense or supply. In other cases substitution is assumed and the clinician has to explicitly request non-substitution.

at0139.description: An indicator of the urgency with which the ordered item should be dispensed.
at0139.comment: For example 'Urgent'. This is left to be templated or specialised according to local valuesets. Some jurisdictions allow instructions to dispense to be marked as 'urgent' so that the dispensary handles them quickly.

at0143.description: Structured details about the overall preparation including strength, form and constituent substances.
at0143.comment: Use this SLOT where the detailed description of the ordered item needs to be explicitly stated. For example: the form, strength, any diluents or mixture of ingredients.

at0146.description: The unit for the maximum amount allowed.
at0146.comment: For example: 'tablet','mg'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

at0148.description: The overall therapeutic intent of the ordered item.
at0148.comment: For example: 'pain relief'; 'palliative care'; 'low-dose prophylaxis'; 'rehydration'; 'nutritional infusion'.

at0150.description: Details about the total daily amount of the ordered item expected to be administered.
at0150.comment: The total daily dose records the expected effective dose, and thus support titration of an initial low dose towards the effective dose over a period of time. This is not itself the target dose or goal but the actual effective daily dose against that goal. In some circumstances the Total daily dose will be calcuable from computable directions, in others it may need to be manually entered.

at0151.description: The amount of ordered item which will be taken each day if administered as intended.

at0152.description: The dose unit associated with the total daily amount.
at0152.comment: The dose units are normally scientific units such as mg, ml rather than 'tablets'.

at0154.description: The reason why an ordered item should not be substituted at dispense.

at0155.description: The date from which the ordered item is permitted to be dispensed for the first time.
at0155.comment: May be used to control the time of dispensing of medications with potential for abuse. For example: benzodiazepines or analgesics.

at0161.description: The date after which the ordered item is no longer valid to be legally dispensed.
at0161.comment: In some jurisdictions, orders to dispense may have an expiry date after which the prescription may not be dispensed.

at0162.description: The reason for a clinical safety or maximum dose override.
at0162.comment: For example: 'Not responsive at maximum recommended dose. Critical situation.', 'Peniciilin is only valid treatment, likelihood of true penicillin allergy is low'.

at0165.description: Description of the reason for recording a total daily effective dose.
at0165.comment:
For example: 'Hypertension control', 'Target dose 20mg daily'. The description could be used to identify a name, phrase or paragraph about the purpose for recording total daily effective dose, commonly to allow to titration towards a specific target dose.
The goal or target dose might be recorded here or more commonly as part of a linked EVALUATION 'Goal' archetype.

at0166.description: Additional structured details about the ordered item not captured in other fields.

at0167.description: Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.

at0168.description: Substitution of the medication with a bioequivalent medication is allowed.

at0169.description: Substitution of the medication with a bioequivalent medication is not allowed.

at0170.description: Further details related to dispense directions.
at0170.comment: This SLOT allows for local variation in the different jurisdictions regarding medication dispensing.

at0171.description: A known or recognised safety issue which applies to this subject and the ordered item, such as an allergy, drug duplication warning or contraindication. This element is normally only recorded when this safety advice is overridden.

at0173.description: A narrative description of a specific part of overall directions.
at0173.comment: In some settings, it is common to split overall narrative directions into more specific segments of narrative. For example in hospital settings, it can be common to split the overall directions into 'Dose amount' and 'Dose timing', both as narrative text. These terms can be applied at template or run-time.

at0174.description: A description of the justification used to calculate a dose amount or administration rate where this is dependent on some other factor.

at0177.description: Details of structured dose and timing directions.

at0178.description: Overriding of a known or recognised safety issue which applies to this subject and the ordered item, such as an allergy, drug duplication warning or contraindication.

controls.label: Recommendation
controls.description: Narrative description of the recommendation.

termDefinition.description: Narrative description of the recommendation.
termDefinition.comment: May be coded, using a terminology, if required.

controls.label: Rationale
controls.description: Justifications for the recommendation.

termDefinition.description: Justifications for the recommendation.

at0000.description: A suggestion, advice or proposal for clinical management.

at0002.comment: May be coded, using a terminology, if required.

at0005.description: Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
at0005.comment: For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

controls.label: Service name
controls.description: The name of the single service or activity requested.

termDefinition.description: The name of the single service or activity requested.
termDefinition.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

controls.label: Description
controls.description: Narrative description about the service requested.

termDefinition.description: Narrative description about the service requested.
termDefinition.comment: This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.

controls.label: Reason for request
controls.description: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.

termDefinition.description: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.
termDefinition.comment: Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.

controls.label: Reason description
controls.description: Narrative description about the reason for request.

termDefinition.description: Narrative description about the reason for request.
termDefinition.comment: For example: 'The patient's diabetes has recently become more difficult to stabilise and renal function is deteriorating'.

controls.label: Clinical indication
controls.description: The clinical reason for the ordered service.

termDefinition.description: The clinical reason for the ordered service.
termDefinition.comment: Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.

controls.label: Urgency
controls.description: Urgency of the request for service.

termDefinition.description: Urgency of the request for service.
termDefinition.comment: Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. If explicit timing is required then the Service period should be clearly stated.

controls.label: Supplementary information
controls.description: Supplementary information will be following request.

termDefinition.description: Supplementary information will be following request.
termDefinition.comment: Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.

controls.label: Information description
controls.description: Description of the supplementary information.

termDefinition.description: Description of the supplementary information.

controls.label: Comment
controls.description: Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.

termDefinition.description: Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.

at0000.description: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.

at0008.description: @ internal @

at0009.description: @ internal @

at0010.description: The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
at0010.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

at0011.description: The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
at0011.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

at0040.description: The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.
at0040.comment: This data element allows for recording of the timing for a single service, either as a date and time, a date ranges or a text descriptor which can allow for 'next available. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.

at0062.description: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.
at0062.comment: Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.

at0064.description: Narrative description about the reason for request.
at0064.comment: For example: 'The patient's diabetes has recently become more difficult to stabilise and renal function is deteriorating'.

at0065.description: Description of the intent for the request.
at0065.comment: For example: a referral to a specialist may have the intent of the specialist taking over responsibility for care of the patient, or it may be to provide a second opinion on treatment options. Coding of the 'Intent' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

at0068.description: Urgency of the request for service.
at0068.comment: Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. If explicit timing is required then the Service period should be clearly stated.

at0076.description: Supplementary information will be following request.
at0076.comment: Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.

at0112.description: Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
at0112.comment: For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

at0116.description: Language, transport or other personal requirements to support the patient's attendance or participation in provision of the service.

at0121.description: The name of the single service or activity requested.
at0121.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

at0127.description: The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester.
at0127.comment: Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

at0128.description: Details of additional clinicians, organisations or agencies who require copies of any communication.

at0132.description: Additional detail about the service requested.
at0132.comment: For example: Specimen details for a laboratory test request, or anatomical location for a procedure request.

at0135.description: Narrative description about the service requested.
at0135.comment: This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.

at0141.description: Details about the clinician or organisation requesting the service.

at0142.description: Details about the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.

at0144.description: The date/time that marks the conclusion of the clinically valid period of time for delivery of this service.
at0144.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the latest possible date for service delivery or to the date of expiry for this request. For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.

at0145.description: The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for delivery of this service.
at0145.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the earliest possible date for service delivery. For example: sometimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some procedures can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking medications for a specific amount of time.

at0147.description: The valid period for this request is open ended and has no date of expiry.
at0147.comment: Record as TRUE to record explicity that the request has no expiry date. For example: commonly required for a referral to a specialist for long-term or lifelong care.

at0148.comment: Coding of the 'Service type' with a coding system is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code. For example: biochemistry or microbiology laboratory, ultrasound or CT imaging.

at0149.description: Digital document, image, video or diagram supplied as additional information to support or inform the request.

at0150.description: Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.

at0151.description: Details about a complex service request requiring a sequence of timings.
at0151.comment: For example: 'hourly vital signs observations for 4 hours, then 4 hourly for 20 hours' or 'every third Wednesday for 3 visits' or .

at0152.description: The clinical reason for the ordered service.
at0152.comment: Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.
